elements.content: Monitoring hypoxia-related changes in subcellular organelles would provide deeper insights into hypoxia-related metabolic pathways, further helping us to recognize various diseases on subcellular level. However, there is still a lack of real-time, in situ, and controllable means for biosensing in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions. Herein, we report a reductase and light programmatical gated nanodevice via integrating light-responsive DNA probes into a hypoxia-responsive metal–organic framework for spatiotemporally controlled imaging of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions. A small-molecule-decorated strategy was applied to endow the nanodevice with the ability to target subcellular organelles. Dynamic changes of mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate under hypoxic conditions were chosen as a model physiological process. The assay was validated in living cells and tumor tissue slices obtained from mice models. Due to the highly integrated, easily accessible, and available for living cells and tissues, we envision that the concept and methodology can be further extended to monitor biomolecules in other subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions with a spatiotemporal controllable approach.

elements.content: Subcellular organelles (mitochondria, nucleus, lysosomes, etc.) as important organelles are involved in many significant physiological processes, such as cell proliferation, intracellular transport, and biological metabolism. Dysfunction of these organelles would cause various abnormal regulations and many serious diseases. Not surprisingly, mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with a variety of human diseases, including neurodegenerative and neuromuscular disorders, ischemia–reperfusion injury, and cancer. Based on this, lots of research works have been focused on the study of subcellular organelles. Hypoxia, as a typical feature of a solid tumor, has been widely recognized to induce cellular dysfunction and lead to incredible changes of biomolecules in subcellular organelles, such as hydrogen ions in lysosomes, adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in mitochondria, and so forth. Monitoring the changes of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions would provide deeper insights into hypoxia-related metabolic pathways, further helping us to recognize various diseases on the subcellular level. However, there is still a lack of probe system capable of monitoring the state of organelles under hypoxic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Subcellular organelles (mitochondria, nucleus, lysosomes, etc.) as important organelles are involved in many significant physiological processes, such as cell proliferation, intracellular transport, and biological metabolism. Dysfunction of these organelles would cause various abnormal regulations and many serious diseases. Not surprisingly, mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with a variety of human diseases, including neurodegenerative and neuromuscular disorders, ischemia-reperfusion injury, and cancer. Based on this, lots of research works have been focused on the study of subcellular organelles. Hypoxia, as a typical feature of a solid tumor, has been widely recognized to induce cellular dysfunction and lead to incredible changes of biomolecules in subcellular organelles, such as hydrogen ions in lysosomes, adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in mitochondria, and so forth. Monitoring the changes of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions would provide deeper insights into hypoxia-related metabolic pathways, further helping us to recognize various diseases on the subcellular level. However, there is still a lack of probe system capable of monitoring the state of organelles under hypoxic conditions.

elements.content: Owing to the unique advantages of high spatiotemporal resolution, sensitivity, and simplicity imparted by optical imaging, extensive efforts have been made in recent decades to develop various fluorescent probes for detection of intracellular biomolecules. Since it can remain stable during circulation and easily be activated at desired sites of action, on-demand activated fluorescent probes with spatiotemporal resolution serve as a promising tool in basic research and therapeutic applications. Light is the most attractive noninvasive regulatory entity because it can be controlled spatially and temporally without contaminating the reaction system. Recently, many strategies have been proposed to design spatiotemporally gated fluorescent probes by incorporating photosensitive groups into DNA assembly to control cell function or affect biological pathways or gene expression. For example, Li and co-workers reported a series of near-infrared (NIR) light-mediated, spatiotemporally controlled sensing technology for intracellular or subcellular organelle imaging and therapy. However, some major challenges still exist. Since the probes used in previous reports lack specific targeting ability to organelles and can only sense biomolecules in organelles under normoxia, there is still much room for improvement in the study of spatiotemporally controlled imaging of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions.

elements.content: Inspired by this, we proposed a reductase and light programmatical gated nanodevice via integrating light-responsive DNA probes into a hypoxia-responsive metal–organic framework (MOF) for spatiotemporally controlled monitoring biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions. Considering that mitochondrion is one of the most important subcellular organelles involved in cellular regulation while the turbulence to mitochondrial ATP would inevitably lead to alterations in cell activity, controllable monitoring mitochondrial ATP under hypoxic conditions was chosen as a model physiological process. Herein, the nanodevice we constructed contained two elements in composition. First, a Y-shaped nucleic acid aptamer (Y-apt) consists of three single strands (Ya, Yb, and Yc-PC), among which, Ya was designed to contain an aptamer sequence responsive to ATP, while Yc-PC was designed to contain a photocleavable (PC) linker, which can be cleaved via one-photon (OP) or two-photon (TP) irradiation. It is worth noting that the unilluminated Y-apt was remained in an inert state even in the presence of target molecules. Under this circumstance, the Cy3 labeled at the 5′-end of Ya and the Cy5 labeled at the 3′-end of Yb undergo Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET), presenting a signal of “FRET ON”. Upon irradiation with light, the PC linkers contained in Yc-PC were quickly cleaved, which would thus activate the sensitivity of Y-apt to ATP and then underwent conformational changes, which can induce “FRET OFF”. Second, MOF composed of ferric ions (Fe3+) bridged by organic ligands (4,4′-azobisbenzoic acid contained hypoxia-responsive unit, can be reduced by hypoxia-related reductase in cells (Scheme S1B) was employed as a reductase-gated nanocarrier and a nanoquencher. The above-mentioned Y-apt and MOF were assembled by adsorbing negatively charged Y-apt onto the surface of the hypoxia-responsive MOF via an electrostatic interaction. Once the constructed MOF@Y-apt entered the hypoxic cancer cells (), MOF@Y-apt was degraded by the hypoxia-related high expressed reductase and thus cause the release of Y-apt. Significantly, cyanine dyes, such as Cy3, Cy5, and Cy5.5, possess the ability to specifically target mitochondria in cancer cells. Therefore, the released light-gated Y-apt can response to mitochondrial ATP and an output fluorescent signal under the targeting effect of cyanine dyes. Additionally, the fluorescence of Cy5.5 labeled on Yc-PC was available as an internal standard for Cy3 fluorescence self-correction, which can effectively improve the accuracy of the imaging results. More importantly, compared with some previous works using PC linker as a spatiotemporally controlled element, our scheme further utilized TP excitation, which can avoid cell damage and possess ideal tissue penetration depth to achieve the purpose of photolysis. We demonstrated that this reductase and light programmatical gated nanodevice could not only effectively deliver into the mitochondria of hypoxic cells but also spatiotemporal control its ATP fluorescence sensing activity in vitro and tumor tissues by light irradiation. Due to the highly integrated, easily accessible, and available for living cells and tissues, we envision that the concept and methodology can be further extended to biorecognition in other subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions using the spatiotemporal controllable approach.

elements.content: Ferric chloride (FeCl3), 4,4′-azobisbenzoic acid (H2AzDc), and sodium dithionite (Na2S2O4) were purchased from Energy Chemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company Ltd. (Shanghai, China). ATP disodium salt hydrate was obtained from Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Mito-Tracker Green was purchased from KeyGEN BioTECH (Beijing, China), and JC-1 was purchased from APExBIO Technology (Houston, USA). Ultrapure water obtained from the Millipore Milli-Q water purification system (18.2 MΩ) was used in all assays. The DNA oligonucleotides were synthesized by Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China) and purified by high-performance liquid chromatography. The sequences are shown in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Reagents

Ferric chloride (FeCl3), 4,4'-azobisbenzoic acid (H2AzDc), and sodium dithionite (Na2S2O4) were purchased from Energy Chemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company Ltd. (Shanghai, China). ATP disodium salt hydrate was obtained from Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Mito-Tracker Green was purchased from KeyGEN BioTECH (Beijing, China), and JC-1 was purchased from APExBIO Technology (Houston, USA). Ultrapure water obtained from the Millipore Milli-Q water purification system (18.2 MΩ) was used in all assays. The DNA oligonucleotides were synthesized by Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China) and purified by high-performance liquid chromatography. The sequences are shown in Table S1.

elements.content: Y-apt was formed by mixing Ya, Yb, and Yc-PC in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, supplemented with 5 mM MgCl2, pH = 7.4), heating together at 95 °C (5 min) for annealing, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resultant product was monitored by 12% polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE, 100 V, 60 min). Then, MOF@Y-apt was finally obtained by adding 1 mg of synthesized MOF in 10 mM PBS (pH = 7.4) containing Y-apt, mixed for 30 min, followed by centrifugation and washing.
elements.clean_text:
Construction of Y-apt and MOF@Y-apt

Y-apt was formed by mixing Ya, Yb, and Yc-PC in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, supplemented with 5 mM MgCl2, pH = 7.4), heating together at 95 °C (5 min) for annealing, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resultant product was monitored by 12% polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE, 100 V, 60 min). Then, MOF@Y-apt was finally obtained by adding 1 mg of synthesized MOF in 10 mM PBS (pH = 7.4) containing Y-apt, mixed for 30 min, followed by centrifugation and washing.

elements.content: Different concentrations of ATP (final concentrations of 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, and 3 mM) were mixed with 50 nM control probes (Y-apt-on and Y-apt-off) in PBS (supplemented with 5 mM MgCl2, pH = 8.0), respectively, and then incubated at room temperature for 20 min. For the light-gated sensing assay, Y-apt or Y-apt-off was incubated with different concentrations of ATP, followed by light exposure (365 nm, 10 min). For the selectivity assays, uridine triphosphate (UTP), cytidine triphosphate (CTP), and guanosine triphosphate (GTP) were added at final concentrations of 3 mM to the mixture instead of ATP and then incubated for another 20 min at room temperature. The fluorescence spectra from 540 to 750 nm were collected under an excitation wavelength of 530 nm.
elements.clean_text:
ATP Sensing Assay in Aqueous Solution

Different concentrations of ATP (final concentrations of 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, and 3 mM) were mixed with 50 nM control probes (Y-apt-on and Y-apt-off) in PBS (supplemented with 5 mM MgCl2, pH = 8.0), respectively, and then incubated at room temperature for 20 min. For the light-gated sensing assay, Y-apt or Y-apt-off was incubated with different concentrations of ATP, followed by light exposure (365 nm, 10 min). For the selectivity assays, uridine triphosphate (UTP), cytidine triphosphate (CTP), and guanosine triphosphate (GTP) were added at final concentrations of 3 mM to the mixture instead of ATP and then incubated for another 20 min at room temperature. The fluorescence spectra from 540 to 750 nm were collected under an excitation wavelength of 530 nm.

elements.content: The human breast adenocarcinoma (MCF-7) cells (1 × 105 cells per well) were seeded in confocal culture dishes for 24 h and incubated with 0.1 mg·mL–1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and then treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Subsequently, the cells were exposed to 365 nm light for 10 min and then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. Finally, the MOF@Y-apt-incubated MCF-7 cells were washed three times with Dulbecco’s phosphate-buffered saline (D-PBS) and subjected to imaging by a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope (conditions: Cy3 fluorescence channel, λex = 561 nm and λem = 570–620 nm; Cy5 fluorescence channel, λex = 561 nm and λem = 625–680 nm; and Cy5.5 fluorescent channel, λex = 640 nm and λem = 663–738 nm). To demonstrate the feasibility of MOF@Y-apt for monitoring the fluctuation of mitochondrial ATP under hypoxic conditions, MCF-7 cells were pre-treated with cell culture medium containing sodium azide (NaN3, 10 mM) or calcium chloride (CaCl2, 5 mM) for 1 h, respectively. The cell samples were then incubated with 0.1 mg·mL–1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Subsequently, the cells were exposed with 365 nm light (OP) for 10 min and then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. Finally, the MOF@Y-apt-incubated MCF-7 cells were washed three times with D-PBS and subjected to imaging by a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Monitoring Mitochondrial ATP in Hypoxic Cancer Cells by MOF@Y-apt

The human breast adenocarcinoma (MCF-7) cells (1 × 105 cells per well) were seeded in confocal culture dishes for 24 h and incubated with 0.1 mg⋅mL-1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and then treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Subsequently, the cells were exposed to 365 nm light for 10 min and then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. Finally, the MOF@Y-apt-incubated MCF-7 cells were washed three times with Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (D-PBS) and subjected to imaging by a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope (conditions: Cy3 fluorescence channel, λex = 561 nm and λem = 570-620 nm; Cy5 fluorescence channel, λex = 561 nm and λem = 625-680 nm; and Cy5.5 fluorescent channel, λex = 640 nm and λem = 663-738 nm). To demonstrate the feasibility of MOF@Y-apt for monitoring the fluctuation of mitochondrial ATP under hypoxic conditions, MCF-7 cells were pre-treated with cell culture medium containing sodium azide (NaN3, 10 mM) or calcium chloride (CaCl2, 5 mM) for 1 h, respectively. The cell samples were then incubated with 0.1 mg⋅mL-1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Subsequently, the cells were exposed with 365 nm light (OP) for 10 min and then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. Finally, the MOF@Y-apt-incubated MCF-7 cells were washed three times with D-PBS and subjected to imaging by a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope.

elements.content: MCF-7 cells (1 × 105 cells per well) were seeded at confocal culture dishes for 24 h and incubated with MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and then treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Before TP irradiation, the cells were washed three times with D-PBS. The TP light source was an 80 MHz mode-locked Mai-TaiTi-Sapphire pulsed laser (690–1040 nm) which tuned to 740 nm for MOF@Y-apt-incubated cells.
elements.clean_text:
Imaging Mitochondrial ATP Using TP Light Source

MCF-7 cells (1 × 105 cells per well) were seeded at confocal culture dishes for 24 h and incubated with MOF@Y-apt for 2 h and then treated for another 4 h under hypoxic conditions. Before TP irradiation, the cells were washed three times with D-PBS. The TP light source was an 80 MHz mode-locked Mai-TaiTi-Sapphire pulsed laser (690-1040 nm) which tuned to 740 nm for MOF@Y-apt-incubated cells.

elements.content: The female BALB/c nude mice were used to set up a tumor xenograft model. MCF-7 cells [1 × 106 cells/100 μL in 1:1 (v/v) PBS and Matrigel] were injected subcutaneously into the back of the mice. When the tumors grew to 200–400 mm3, mice were euthanized to collect the tumor. Then, the tumor was cryosectioned at −20 °C into slices of 50 μm thick and treated with 0.1 mg·mL–1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium at 37 °C. Thereafter, the tissue slices were washed three times with D-PBS to remove free MOF@Y-apt, followed by TP (λ = 740 nm) imaging of the tissue slices using a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Tissue Imaging of MCF-7 Tumor-Bearing Mice

The female BALB/c nude mice were used to set up a tumor xenograft model. MCF-7 cells [1 × 106 cells/100 μL in 1:1 (v/v) PBS and Matrigel] were injected subcutaneously into the back of the mice. When the tumors grew to 200-400 mm3, mice were euthanized to collect the tumor. Then, the tumor was cryosectioned at -20 °C into slices of 50 μm thick and treated with 0.1 mg⋅mL-1 of MOF@Y-apt for 2 h in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium at 37 °C. Thereafter, the tissue slices were washed three times with D-PBS to remove free MOF@Y-apt, followed by TP (λ = 740 nm) imaging of the tissue slices using a Nikon A1R MP multiphoton and confocal microscope.

elements.content: The design of spatiotemporally controlled Y-apt for monitoring mitochondrial ATP is illustrated in A. Y-apt is formed by annealing of Ya (an aptamer responsive to ATP), Yb, and Yc-PC (which is obtained by incorporating a PC linker at positions spaced by 10 nucleotides at the 5′-end). In the SYBR Green-stained PAGE image (B), one band with the highest molecular weight can be observed on the gel, while the mobility is lower than other bands, indicating the successful assembly of Y-apt (lane 7). To achieve high-efficiency synthesis of Y-apt, the molar ratio of Ya, Yb, and Yc-PC was optimized to be 1:1.25:1.25 (Figure S1). Additionally, we designed two control probes, Y-apt-off (lane 4 in Figure S2 and Scheme S3A) formed by annealing Ya, Yb, and Yc-non (its sequence is identical to Yc-PC but without the PC linker) and Y-apt-on (lane 6 in Figure S2 and Scheme S3B) formed by Ya, Yb, Yc-1, and Yc-2 (Yc-1 and Yc-2 are DNA sequences that mimic disconnection due to the photocleavage of the PC linker in Yc-PC, respectively). It is remarkable that the PC linker on Yc-PC can be quickly cleaved upon irradiation, which further ensures the sensitivity of Y-apt to target ATP (A). Upon light exposure, it can be observed that Y-apt appears a distinct faster migrating band upon light exposure (C, lane 7), which was in a similar position to Y-apt-on (lane 4), indicating that light can remotely control the cleavage of the PC linker. Furthermore, the bands become brighter when the illumination time was prolonged (Figure S3). Then, the effective response of Y-apt to ATP upon illumination was verified. The illuminated Y-apt showed two distinct short bands (C, lane 8) upon ATP addition. With the increase of ATP concentration (from 0 to 10 mM), the short bands in response to ATP in the gel image became brighter (Figure S4). The control probes (Y-apt-off and Y-apt-on) also validated the effective response of our constructed nanodevice to ATP. As shown in Figure S5, Y-apt-on showed obvious short bands compared with Y-apt-off upon ATP addition, suggesting that only light-gated Y-shaped probes could response to ATP. These results all indicated that light is an indispensable tool for regulating Y-apt response to ATP.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Construction and Characterization of Y-apt and Its Response to ATP

The design of spatiotemporally controlled Y-apt for monitoring mitochondrial ATP is illustrated in A. Y-apt is formed by annealing of Ya (an aptamer responsive to ATP), Yb, and Yc-PC (which is obtained by incorporating a PC linker at positions spaced by 10 nucleotides at the 5'-end). In the SYBR Green-stained PAGE image (B), one band with the highest molecular weight can be observed on the gel, while the mobility is lower than other bands, indicating the successful assembly of Y-apt (lane 7). To achieve high-efficiency synthesis of Y-apt, the molar ratio of Ya, Yb, and Yc-PC was optimized to be 1:1.25:1.25 (Figure S1). Additionally, we designed two control probes, Y-apt-off (lane 4 in Figure S2 and Scheme S3A) formed by annealing Ya, Yb, and Yc-non (its sequence is identical to Yc-PC but without the PC linker) and Y-apt-on (lane 6 in Figure S2 and Scheme S3B) formed by Ya, Yb, Yc-1, and Yc-2 (Yc-1 and Yc-2 are DNA sequences that mimic disconnection due to the photocleavage of the PC linker in Yc-PC, respectively). It is remarkable that the PC linker on Yc-PC can be quickly cleaved upon irradiation, which further ensures the sensitivity of Y-apt to target ATP (A). Upon light exposure, it can be observed that Y-apt appears a distinct faster migrating band upon light exposure (C, lane 7), which was in a similar position to Y-apt-on (lane 4), indicating that light can remotely control the cleavage of the PC linker. Furthermore, the bands become brighter when the illumination time was prolonged (Figure S3). Then, the effective response of Y-apt to ATP upon illumination was verified. The illuminated Y-apt showed two distinct short bands (C, lane 8) upon ATP addition. With the increase of ATP concentration (from 0 to 10 mM), the short bands in response to ATP in the gel image became brighter (Figure S4). The control probes (Y-apt-off and Y-apt-on) also validated the effective response of our constructed nanodevice to ATP. As shown in Figure S5, Y-apt-on showed obvious short bands compared with Y-apt-off upon ATP addition, suggesting that only light-gated Y-shaped probes could response to ATP. These results all indicated that light is an indispensable tool for regulating Y-apt response to ATP.

elements.content: (A) Design of spatiotemporally controlled Y-apt and its schematic diagram in response to ATP. (B) SYBR Green-stained 12% PAGE imaging was used to verify the formation of Y-apt. Lane 1: Ya; lane 2: Yb; lane 3: Yc-PC; lane 4: double strand formed by hybridization of Ya and Yb (Ya + Yb); lane 5: double strand formed by hybridization of Ya and Yc-PC (Ya + Yc-PC); lane 6: double strand formed by hybridization of Yb and Yc-PC (Yb + Yc-PC); and lane 7: Y-apt. The final concentration of the DNA samples was 1 μM. (C) SYBR Green-stained 12% PAGE imaging. Lane 1: Ya; lane 2: Yb + Yc-PC; lane 3: double strand formed by hybridization of Yb, Yc-1, and Yc-2 (Yb + Yc-1 + Yc-2); lane 4: Y-apt-on; lane 5: Y-apt; lane 6: addition of ATP to Y-apt-containing solutions without light irradiation (Y-apt + ATP); lane 7: Y-apt-containing solutions after light irradiation (Y-apt + hv); and lane 8: addition of ATP to Y-apt-containing solutions with light irradiation (Y-apt + hv + ATP). The final concentration of the DNA samples was 1 μM. For the required light irradiation, 365 nm light at a density of 2.2 mW·cm–2 was applied for 10 min. The concentration of ATP was 10 mM.

elements.content: Subsequently, a set of fluorescence experiments were carried out to further confirm the sensitivity of Y-apt to ATP. Cy3 was modified at the 5′-end of Ya while the Cy5 label at the 3′-end of Yb to form fluorescent Y-apt. With this dye-labeling strategy, the response of Y-apt to ATP could be evaluated by the signal change of FRET between Cy3 and Cy5 upon light irradiation. As shown in Figure S6A, when ATP was added into the solution containing Y-apt followed by light irradiation, the increase in ATP concentration rapidly weakened the FRET signal between Cy3 and Cy5. This was mainly because, with the increase of ATP concentration, more and more aptamer will bind to ATP and thus lead to the interruption of FRET from Cy3 to Cy5, followed by light irradiation. In contrast, there was no evident fluorescence change in the mixed solution of Y-apt and ATP without light irradiation (Figure S6B), indicating that the original Y-shaped structure could effectively inhibit the sensing activity of Y-apt. Compared with the mixture of Y-apt and ATP activated by light, there was no obvious signal change in the presence of UTP, CTP, or GTP, which indicated that the constructed Y-apt had good specificity for ATP over other triphosphate nucleotides (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: Subsequently, a set of fluorescence experiments were carried out to further confirm the sensitivity of Y-apt to ATP. Cy3 was modified at the 5'-end of Ya while the Cy5 label at the 3'-end of Yb to form fluorescent Y-apt. With this dye-labeling strategy, the response of Y-apt to ATP could be evaluated by the signal change of FRET between Cy3 and Cy5 upon light irradiation. As shown in Figure S6A, when ATP was added into the solution containing Y-apt followed by light irradiation, the increase in ATP concentration rapidly weakened the FRET signal between Cy3 and Cy5. This was mainly because, with the increase of ATP concentration, more and more aptamer will bind to ATP and thus lead to the interruption of FRET from Cy3 to Cy5, followed by light irradiation. In contrast, there was no evident fluorescence change in the mixed solution of Y-apt and ATP without light irradiation (Figure S6B), indicating that the original Y-shaped structure could effectively inhibit the sensing activity of Y-apt. Compared with the mixture of Y-apt and ATP activated by light, there was no obvious signal change in the presence of UTP, CTP, or GTP, which indicated that the constructed Y-apt had good specificity for ATP over other triphosphate nucleotides (Figure S7).

Preparation of Reductase and Light Programmatical Gated Nanodevice for ATP Sensing

The hypoxia-responsive MOF was synthesized by a one-step solvothermal method using Fe3+ and 4,4'-azodibenzoic acid (H2AzDc) according to the previous literature (Scheme S1A). The morphology of the as-prepared MOF was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), demonstrated its rod-like structure with good monodispersibility, and an average size distribution of approximately 158.5 ± 4.6 nm in length and 20.4 ± 4.8 nm in width (A). This result was consistent with the dynamic light scattering (DLS) characterization (B, black curve). The zeta potential measurements showed that the charge of the MOF was 32.1 ± 0.6 mV (C, blue column), which was mainly attributed to the abundant Fe3+ on the surface of MOF. Then, the presence of azobenzene units in the MOF was confirmed by UV-vis spectroscopy (D) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (E), respectively.

elements.content: Next, MOF@Y-apt was fabricated by adsorbing negatively charged Y-apt onto the surface of a hypoxia-responsive MOF via and electrostatic interaction (Scheme S2). DLS analysis indicated that the mean length of MOF@Y-apt was 202.2 ± 12.7 nm (B, red curve). As shown in C, the zeta potential of MOF@Y-apt was −14.5 ± 0.4 mV (yellow column), which further confirmed the successful loading of Y-apt. Moreover, the fluorescence of -Cy3 (Y-apt that only Ya labeled Cy3, Yb and Yc-PC were label free) could be effectually quenched by MOF owing to the charge transferred from Cy3 to Fe3+. According to F­(a,b) and S8, we calculated that about 93.6% Y-Cy3 can be adsorbed on MOF. To confirm the above-mentioned results, PAGE was also further employed. When the MOF was added into the solution containing Y-Cy3 (inset of F­(a)), we could not observe the obvious DNA band collected from the supernatant of MOF@Y-Cy3-contained solution after centrifugation (inset of F­(b)). Additionally, the mean lengths and zeta potential of MOF@Y-apt upon treatment with cell culture medium (containing 10% fetal bovine serum) for 24 h did not demonstrate the obvious change compared with those of the untreated group (Figures S9 and S10), which indicated that MOF@Y-apt could remain relatively stable in a complex biological environment.

As shown in C, the zeta potential of MOF@Y-apt was -14.5 ± 0.4 mV (yellow column), which further confirmed the successful loading of Y-apt. elements.content: With the constructed MOF@Y-apt in hand, we next tested the feasibility of MOF@Y-apt for reductase-gated release of Y-apt. It has been reported that sodium dithionite (Na2S2O4), a reducing agent, plays a crucial role in the reduction of azo bonds to amine groups. Therefore, the hypoxia responsiveness of our constructed MOF@Y-apt was assessed by using Na2S2O4. The TEM image indicates that the diameter of MOF obviously decreased when Na2S2O4 is introduced into the MOF-containing solutions, and the morphology also changed significantly (inset of A), while the mean size determined by DLS changed obviously (B, blue curve). The UV–vis spectra (D, blue curve) showed that the maximum absorbance of the MOF decreased obviously upon treatment with Na2S2O4. Meanwhile, FTIR measurements (E, blue curve) further showed that the absorption peak of NN bond in the MOF at 1425 cm–1 disappeared upon addition of Na2S2O4, which is consistent with the previous report. These results indicated the successful hypoxia-induced decomposition of azobenzene bridges and efficient degradation of MOF. Furthermore, the fluorescence emission intensity of Cy3 increased significantly upon Na2S2O4 addition, which indicated that Y-Cy3 can be released from the reduced MOF (F­(d)). Additionally, a bright DNA band was observed in the sample collecting from the supernatant of the MOF@Y-Cy3-containing solution upon Na2S2O4 addition (inset of F­(d)). These results demonstrated that the MOF possessed unique hypoxia-responsive decomposition property.

elements.content: Next, we explored the response of MOF@Y-apt to ATP in aqueous solutions, followed by reductase-gated Y-apt release. As can be seen from A, the fluorescence signal of the solution containing MOF@Y-apt did not change significantly before (curve a) and after (curve b) light irradiation under normoxic conditions even upon ATP addition. Then, Na2S2O4 was used to co-incubate with MOF@Y-apt-containing solution to simulate hypoxic environment. The MOF@Y-apt-containing solution upon hypoxia treatment was divided into three groups: the first group was incubated with ATP and the second group was irradiated by light, while the third group was incubated with ATP, followed by light exposure. As displayed in A, a distinct “FRET ON” signal between Cy3 and Cy5 was observed from the first group (curve c), while the FRET signal remained almost unchanged in the second group (curve d). Notably, a significant signal transition (from “FRET ON” to “FRET OFF”) was observed from the third group (curve e). All these data indicate that the MOF@Y-apt gated by hypoxia and light can effectively signal the presence of ATP. Quantitatively, the fluorescence intensity of Cy5 weakened dramatically, while the fluorescence intensity of Cy3 increased significantly upon addition of ATP (0.25–3.0 mM) into Na2S2O4-treated MOF@Y-apt, followed by light irradiation (B). The Cy3 fluorescence enhancement of Y-apt demonstrated approximately linear with ATP concentration over the range of 0.25–3 mM (C). On the contrary, the fluorescence signal was almost unchanged with the increase of ATP concentration without exposure to light irradiation (Figure S11), suggesting that the photocleavage of Y-apt was crucial for this design.

elements.content: After confirming the feasibility of MOF@Y-apt for ATP monitoring under hypoxic conditions in aqueous solution, we investigated its further performance in living MCF-7 cells. First, MOF@Y-apt was supposed to accumulate in the mitochondria of cancer cells due to the mitochondria-targeting characteristic endowed by cyanine dyes. To confirm this, MOF@Y-Cy5.5, in which only Yc-PC was labeled with Cy5.5 while Ya and Yb were label free, was used to track its intracellular location. Commercially available Mito-tracker Green was employed to test the colocalization of MOF@Y-Cy5.5 with mitochondria. Confocal microscopy images (A) showed that the Cy5.5 fluorescence distributed in MCF-7 cells overlapped well with the Mito-tracker Green fluorescence, while the Pearson’s coefficient (PsC) was 0.85 (B). These results validated that labeled Cy5.5 could specifically drive the accumulation of our constructed nanodevice into mitochondria, which laid the foundation for monitoring mitochondrial ATP in living cells (C). Second, whether the nanodevice can damage mitochondria is also an important parameter that must be considered. Since mitochondrial damage may reduce the accuracy of ATP imaging results, we then utilized the JC-1 dye, a commercially mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) indicator, to evaluate the changes in the MMP of MCF-7 cells upon different treatments. JC-1 tends to aggregate (red fluorescence) at high MMP while become a monomer (green fluorescence) at low MMP, so the change of MMP can be easily detected by the conversion of fluorescence color while reflecting the depolarization of mitochondria. As can be seen from Figure S12, the fluorescence signal obtained from MCF-7 cells upon various treatments did not differ significantly from that of the control group without any treatment, suggesting that hypoxia, light, or incubation of the nanodevice constructed by us did not cause detectable mitochondrial damage, which can ensure the accuracy of imaging results. Finally, the cytotoxicity of the constructed nanodevice in MCF-7 cells could be another concern. As shown in Figure S13, MCF-7 cells maintained high cell viability upon treatment with different concentrations of MOF@Y-apt regardless of light exposure.
elements.clean_text:
Using the Reductase and Light Programmatical Gated DNA Nanodevice for Monitoring Mitochondrial ATP in Hypoxic Cancer Cells

After confirming the feasibility of MOF@Y-apt for ATP monitoring under hypoxic conditions in aqueous solution, we investigated its further performance in living MCF-7 cells. First, MOF@Y-apt was supposed to accumulate in the mitochondria of cancer cells due to the mitochondria-targeting characteristic endowed by cyanine dyes. To confirm this, MOF@Y-Cy5.5, in which only Yc-PC was labeled with Cy5.5 while Ya and Yb were label free, was used to track its intracellular location. Commercially available Mito-tracker Green was employed to test the colocalization of MOF@Y-Cy5.5 with mitochondria. Confocal microscopy images (A) showed that the Cy5.5 fluorescence distributed in MCF-7 cells overlapped well with the Mito-tracker Green fluorescence, while the Pearson's coefficient (PsC) was 0.85 (B). These results validated that labeled Cy5.5 could specifically drive the accumulation of our constructed nanodevice into mitochondria, which laid the foundation for monitoring mitochondrial ATP in living cells (C). Second, whether the nanodevice can damage mitochondria is also an important parameter that must be considered. Since mitochondrial damage may reduce the accuracy of ATP imaging results, we then utilized the JC-1 dye, a commercially mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) indicator, to evaluate the changes in the MMP of MCF-7 cells upon different treatments. JC-1 tends to aggregate (red fluorescence) at high MMP while become a monomer (green fluorescence) at low MMP, so the change of MMP can be easily detected by the conversion of fluorescence color while reflecting the depolarization of mitochondria. As can be seen from Figure S12, the fluorescence signal obtained from MCF-7 cells upon various treatments did not differ significantly from that of the control group without any treatment, suggesting that hypoxia, light, or incubation of the nanodevice constructed by us did not cause detectable mitochondrial damage, which can ensure the accuracy of imaging results. Finally, the cytotoxicity of the constructed nanodevice in MCF-7 cells could be another concern. As shown in Figure S13, MCF-7 cells maintained high cell viability upon treatment with different concentrations of MOF@Y-apt regardless of light exposure.

elements.content: Then, we evaluated the response of DNA nanodevices to mitochondrial ATP in MCF-7 cells under hypoxic conditions. First, we used MOF@Y-apt-on and MOF@Y-apt-off to investigate its potential for imaging mitochondrial ATP under different conditions. As shown in Figures S14 and S15, no fluorescence demonstrated in MCF-7 cells upon treatment with either MOF@Y-apt-off or MOF@Y-apt-on under normoxia conditions, while bright fluorescence images were obtained from MCF-7 cells upon incubation with MOF@Y-apt-off and MOF@Y-apt-on under hypoxic conditions. Specifically, an obvious FRET signal of Cy5 attained from MOF@Y-apt-off-treated MCF-7 cells was observed under hypoxic conditions, while the Cy3 signal was negligible (Figure S16). This was mainly attributed to the fact that the structure of Y-apt-off released in response to hypoxia was stable, which hindered the further binding of ATP to aptamers. In the same case, the MOF@Y-apt-on-treated MCF-7 cells demonstrated that the Cy5 signal disappeared, while the Cy3 signal evidently increased. The fluorescence recovery of Cy3 suggested that the hypoxia-triggered released Y-apt-on would in turn react with mitochondrial ATP and disrupt FRET between Cy3 and Cy5. Subsequently, MOF@Y-apt was further used to verify the spatiotemporally controlled imaging ability of the nanodevice. As shown in A­(b), an FRET signal of Cy5 was observed, while the Cy3 signal was negligibly attained from hypoxic MCF-7 cells before light irradiation. However, the FRET signal disappeared upon light irradiation (A­(c)), indicating that the photolysis reaction of the nanodevice performed well in living cells. It was worth mentioning that the Cy5.5 labeled on Yc-PC not only guides Y-apt into the mitochondria in cancer cells but also serves as an internal reference for ratiometric analysis. As shown in B­(b,c), the ratio of Cy3/Cy5.5 upon illumination was 9.45-fold higher than that before illumination, which more accurately indicated that the spatiotemporally controlled ability of light to nanodevice plays a crucial role in our strategy.

elements.content: Next, we demonstrated the use of MOF@Y-apt for monitoring the change of mitochondrial ATP level under hypoxia. To accomplish it, MCF-7 cells were pre-treated with 10 mM NaN3 (an inhibitor to decrease cellular ATP concentrations) or 5 mM CaCl2 (Ca2+ has been reported to increase cellular ATP concentrations) and then incubated with MOF@Y-apt under hypoxic conditions, followed by light irradiation. Compared with the untreated cells, a stronger Cy3 fluorescence signal was attained from the Ca2+-treated MCF-7 cells, while a weaker Cy3 fluorescence signal was attained from the NaN3-treated MCF-7 cells upon light irradiation (A­(c–e)). Significantly, the cellular fluorescence ratio (R Cy3/Cy5.5) showed distinct changes depending on the relative expression levels of mitochondrial ATP under hypoxic conditions. As shown in B­(c–e), the ratio of Cy3/Cy5.5 attained from Ca2+-treated MCF-7 cells was about 1.81-fold higher than that of the unpre-treated MCF-7 cells, while the ratio of Cy3/Cy5.5 decreased by about 83.3% in NaN3-treated MCF-7 cells. Taken together, these results demonstrate that our constructed nanodevice can serve as a promising tool to monitor the dynamics change of biomolecules at the level of subcellular organelles under hypoxia.

elements.content: Since activating DNA by using high-energy ultraviolet light in previous designs would harm the living cells, this required us to search for more safer light sources. Fortunately, our group has previously reported that spatiotemporally controlled DNA can be precisely cleaved or activated via TP irradiation. Based on this, the nanodevice we constructed allows the use of TP irradiation as an external regulatory tool, which is much more desirable than ultraviolet light due to its less photodamage and better penetration depth. As a proof of concept, we applied TP irradiation, which was more desirable than ultraviolet light, as an external regulation tool. To understand the photolysis process of Y-apt, a PC linker was described in A, which can be cleaved via OP or TP irradiation. Therefore, Y-apt could be activated through the TP irradiation to open a gap in response to ATP (B). The target region of MCF-7 cells was selected for TP irradiation. As can be seen from Figure S17A, the fluorescence signal obtained from MCF-7 cells upon treatment with MOF@Y-apt under normoxic conditions with or without TP irradiation can be ignored. Conversely, apparent Cy5 fluorescence was observed from hypoxic MCF-7 cells (the cells were incubated with MOF@Y-apt) without TP irradiation under the excitation wavelength of Cy3, which is mainly due to the effective FRET between Cy3 and Cy5 in Y-apt released from MOF@Y-apt (Figures S17B and C). Upon TP irradiation, intense fluorescence of Cy3 obtained from MOF@Y-apt-treated MCF-7 cells under hypoxic conditions while Cy5 fluorescence under the same excitation wavelength was almost negligible.
elements.clean_text:
Application of TP Excitation for Mitochondrial ATP Imaging under Hypoxic Conditions

Since activating DNA by using high-energy ultraviolet light in previous designs would harm the living cells, this required us to search for more safer light sources. Fortunately, our group has previously reported that spatiotemporally controlled DNA can be precisely cleaved or activated via TP irradiation. Based on this, the nanodevice we constructed allows the use of TP irradiation as an external regulatory tool, which is much more desirable than ultraviolet light due to its less photodamage and better penetration depth. As a proof of concept, we applied TP irradiation, which was more desirable than ultraviolet light, as an external regulation tool. To understand the photolysis process of Y-apt, a PC linker was described in A, which can be cleaved via OP or TP irradiation. Therefore, Y-apt could be activated through the TP irradiation to open a gap in response to ATP (B). The target region of MCF-7 cells was selected for TP irradiation. As can be seen from Figure S17A, the fluorescence signal obtained from MCF-7 cells upon treatment with MOF@Y-apt under normoxic conditions with or without TP irradiation can be ignored. Conversely, apparent Cy5 fluorescence was observed from hypoxic MCF-7 cells (the cells were incubated with MOF@Y-apt) without TP irradiation under the excitation wavelength of Cy3, which is mainly due to the effective FRET between Cy3 and Cy5 in Y-apt released from MOF@Y-apt (Figures S17B and C). Upon TP irradiation, intense fluorescence of Cy3 obtained from MOF@Y-apt-treated MCF-7 cells under hypoxic conditions while Cy5 fluorescence under the same excitation wavelength was almost negligible.

elements.content: (A) Photocleavage of PC linker cleaved by OP (λ ≈ 365 nm) or TP (λ = 740 nm) irradiation. (B) Schematic diagram of Y-apt containing PC linker cleaved by OP (λ ≈ 365 nm) or TP (λ = 740 nm) irradiation. (C) Confocal fluorescence images of MCF-7 cells which incubated with MOF@Y-apt (0.1 mg·mL–1) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h before (a) and after (b) TP (λ = 740 nm) irradiation. (D) Confocal fluorescence images of MOF@Y-apt-incubated hypoxic MCF-7 cells under TP (λ = 740 nm) selective irradiation. The boxed area (target area) was selectively irradiated, whereas the area pointed by the red arrow served as the control area (without TP irradiation). The concentration of MOF@Y-apt was 0.1 mg·mL–1. The excitation wavelength of the Cy3 channel (cyan, 570–620 nm) was 561 nm and that of the Cy5 channel (orange, 625–680 nm) was 561 nm. Scale bar: 20 μm.

The boxed area (target area) was selectively irradiated, whereas the area pointed by the red arrow served as the control area (without TP irradiation). The concentration of MOF@Y-apt was 0.1 mg⋅mL-1. The excitation wavelength of the Cy3 channel (cyan, 570-620 nm) was 561 nm and that of the Cy5 channel (orange, 625-680 nm) was 561 nm. Scale bar: 20 μm.

elements.content: Additionally, to further demonstrate the TP photocleavage performance of the released Y-apt, MCF-7 cells were selectively irradiated by TP. MCF-7 cells irradiated by TP were used as the target area (the boxed area, D), and the non-irradiated area was set as the control area (the area pointed by the red arrow, D). As we can see, an apparent FRET signal of Cy5 was observed in the control area. Meanwhile, the Cy5 signal of the target area disappeared, which indicated that the TP irradiation allowed us to control the sensing function of MOF@Y-apt with precise spatiotemporal resolution. These results clearly show that TP irradiation can not only play the role of OP irradiation to achieve precise photocleaved of Y-apt but also effectively avoid the side effects of using OP irradiation.

elements.content: The good performance of the nanodevice in living cells and the ideal tissue penetration depth of the TP laser (λ = 740 nm) motivated us to further investigate the spatiotemporal controlled sensing of MOF@Y-apt in tumor tissues. To achieve this, MCF-7 cell tumor xenografts were established in nude BALB/c mice, and normal/tumor tissue slices were obtained from the mice model. Then, the nanodevices were incubated with normal tissue slices, tumor tissue slices, and tumor tissue slices pretreated with NaN3 or CaCl2 under the regulation of TP laser. As we can see, the Cy3 fluorescence signal obtained from the tumor tissue incubated with MOF@Y-apt was much brighter than that of normal tissue upon TP laser irradiation (Figure S18). This was mainly due to the specific activation of MOF@Y-apt by the high expressed hypoxia-related reductase (low expression in normal tissues) in tumor tissues. Next, we explored the role of TP laser regulation in MOF@Y-apt-incubated tumor tissues. As shown in A­(b,c), compared with the non-irradiated group (exhibited obvious FRET signals of Cy5), the irradiated MOF@Y-apt-treated group showed bright Cy3 fluorescence. For the irradiated group, the fluorescence ratio of Cy3/Cy5 increased significantly compared with the non-irradiated group (B­(b,c)), indicating that the strategy can be used for spatiotemporal controlled imaging of mitochondria ATP in mice tumor tissues. Subsequently, the nanodevice was further applied to NaN3- and CaCl2-pretreated tumor tissue slices to determine the fluctuation of ATP. As shown in B­(d,e), the Cy3 fluorescence attained from CaCl2-pretreated tissues showed an increase obviously (R Cy3/Cy5 = 23.2) relative to the untreated group (R Cy3/Cy5 = 11.6), while NaN3-treated tissues showed the opposite trend (R Cy3/Cy5 = 1.54). Taken together, these data strongly support the potential of using MOF@Y-apt as a smart nanodevice to image ATP in mouse tumor tissues.
elements.clean_text:
Spatiotemporal Controlled Imaging of ATP of MCF-7 Tumor-Bearing Mice Tissues

The good performance of the nanodevice in living cells and the ideal tissue penetration depth of the TP laser (λ = 740 nm) motivated us to further investigate the spatiotemporal controlled sensing of MOF@Y-apt in tumor tissues. To achieve this, MCF-7 cell tumor xenografts were established in nude BALB/c mice, and normal/tumor tissue slices were obtained from the mice model. Then, the nanodevices were incubated with normal tissue slices, tumor tissue slices, and tumor tissue slices pretreated with NaN3 or CaCl2 under the regulation of TP laser. As we can see, the Cy3 fluorescence signal obtained from the tumor tissue incubated with MOF@Y-apt was much brighter than that of normal tissue upon TP laser irradiation (Figure S18). This was mainly due to the specific activation of MOF@Y-apt by the high expressed hypoxia-related reductase (low expression in normal tissues) in tumor tissues. Next, we explored the role of TP laser regulation in MOF@Y-apt-incubated tumor tissues. As shown in A(b,c), compared with the non-irradiated group (exhibited obvious FRET signals of Cy5), the irradiated MOF@Y-apt-treated group showed bright Cy3 fluorescence. For the irradiated group, the fluorescence ratio of Cy3/Cy5 increased significantly compared with the non-irradiated group (B(b,c)), indicating that the strategy can be used for spatiotemporal controlled imaging of mitochondria ATP in mice tumor tissues. Subsequently, the nanodevice was further applied to NaN3- and CaCl2-pretreated tumor tissue slices to determine the fluctuation of ATP. As shown in B(d,e), the Cy3 fluorescence attained from CaCl2-pretreated tissues showed an increase obviously (R Cy3/Cy5 = 23.2) relative to the untreated group (R Cy3/Cy5 = 11.6), while NaN3-treated tissues showed the opposite trend (R Cy3/Cy5 = 1.54). Taken together, these data strongly support the potential of using MOF@Y-apt as a smart nanodevice to image ATP in mouse tumor tissues.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated a multiparameters programmatical gated DNA nanodevice for spatiotemporally controlled imaging of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions. Such an intelligent nanodevice can achieve excellent response to hypoxia environment by degradation of MOF and thus greatly facilitate the release of Y-apt. The released PC linker-containing Y-apt can be activated by light to response ATP with high temporal resolution and output fluorescent signals in mitochondria under the targeting effect of cyanine dyes. As further application, our scheme further utilized TP irradiation to achieve the purpose of photolysis with ideal tissue penetration depth and biocompatibility. Both in vitro and tissue results showed that a smart nanodevice could be successfully applied to visualize the changes of mitochondrial ATP. We expect that this nanodevice can provide a new idea for deeper understanding of hypoxia-related metabolic pathways and thus further promote the development of cancer diagnosis and treatment.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated a multiparameters programmatical gated DNA nanodevice for spatiotemporally controlled imaging of biomolecules in subcellular organelles under hypoxic conditions. Such an intelligent nanodevice can achieve excellent response to hypoxia environment by degradation of MOF and thus greatly facilitate the release of Y-apt. The released PC linker-containing Y-apt can be activated by light to response ATP with high temporal resolution and output fluorescent signals in mitochondria under the targeting effect of cyanine dyes. As further application, our scheme further utilized TP irradiation to achieve the purpose of photolysis with ideal tissue penetration depth and biocompatibility. Both in vitro and tissue results showed that a smart nanodevice could be successfully applied to visualize the changes of mitochondrial ATP. We expect that this nanodevice can provide a new idea for deeper understanding of hypoxia-related metabolic pathways and thus further promote the development of cancer diagnosis and treatment.

cln_elements.content: The hypoxia-responsive MOF was synthesized by a one-step solvothermal method using Fe3+ and 4,4′-azodibenzoic acid (H2AzDc) according to the previous literature (Scheme S1A). The morphology of the as-prepared MOF was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), demonstrated its rod-like structure with good monodispersibility, and an average size distribution of approximately 158.5 ± 4.6 nm in length and 20.4 ± 4.8 nm in width (A). This result was consistent with the dynamic light scattering (DLS) characterization (B, black curve). The zeta potential measurements showed that the charge of the MOF was 32.1 ± 0.6 mV (C, blue column), which was mainly attributed to the abundant Fe3+ on the surface of MOF. Then, the presence of azobenzene units in the MOF was confirmed by UV–vis spectroscopy (D) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (E), respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Reductase and Light Programmatical Gated Nanodevice for ATP Sensing

The hypoxia-responsive MOF was synthesized by a one-step solvothermal method using Fe3+ and 4,4'-azodibenzoic acid (H2AzDc) according to the previous literature (Scheme S1A). The morphology of the as-prepared MOF was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), demonstrated its rod-like structure with good monodispersibility, and an average size distribution of approximately 158.5 ± 4.6 nm in length and 20.4 ± 4.8 nm in width (A). This result was consistent with the dynamic light scattering (DLS) characterization (B, black curve). The zeta potential measurements showed that the charge of the MOF was 32.1 ± 0.6 mV (C, blue column), which was mainly attributed to the abundant Fe3+ on the surface of MOF. Then, the presence of azobenzene units in the MOF was confirmed by UV-vis spectroscopy (D) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (E), respectively.

other properties: size distribution: 158.5 ± 4.6 nm in length, 20.4 ± 4.8 nm in width
presence of azobenzene units confirmed by UV–vis spectroscopy and FTIR spectroscopy

cln_elements.content:
Next, MOF@Y-apt was fabricated by adsorbing negatively charged Y-apt onto the surface of a hypoxia-responsive MOF via and electrostatic interaction (Scheme S2). DLS analysis indicated that the mean length of MOF@Y-apt was 202.2 ± 12.7 nm (B, red curve). As shown in C, the zeta potential of MOF@Y-apt was −14.5 ± 0.4 mV (yellow column), which further confirmed the successful loading of Y-apt. Moreover, the fluorescence of -Cy3 (Y-apt that only Ya labeled Cy3, Yb and Yc-PC were label free) could be effectually quenched by MOF owing to the charge transferred from Cy3 to Fe3+. According to F­(a,b) and S8, we calculated that about 93.6% Y-Cy3 can be adsorbed on MOF. To confirm the above-mentioned results, PAGE was also further employed. When the MOF was added into the solution containing Y-Cy3 (inset of F­(a)), we could not observe the obvious DNA band collected from the supernatant of MOF@Y-Cy3-contained solution after centrifugation (inset of F­(b)). Additionally, the mean lengths and zeta potential of MOF@Y-apt upon treatment with cell culture medium (containing 10% fetal bovine serum) for 24 h did not demonstrate the obvious change compared with those of the untreated group (Figures S9 and S10), which indicated that MOF@Y-apt could remain relatively stable in a complex biological environment.

Spatiotemporal Controlled Imaging of ATP of MCF-7 Tumor-Bearing Mice Tissues

The good performance of the nanodevice in living cells and the ideal tissue penetration depth of the TP laser (λ = 740 nm) motivated us to further investigate the spatiotemporal controlled sensing of MOF@Y-apt in tumor tissues. To achieve this, MCF-7 cell tumor xenografts were established in nude BALB/c mice, and normal/tumor tissue slices were obtained from the mice model. Then, the nanodevices were incubated with normal tissue slices, tumor tissue slices, and tumor tissue slices pretreated with NaN3 or CaCl2 under the regulation of TP laser. As we can see, the Cy3 fluorescence signal obtained from the tumor tissue incubated with MOF@Y-apt was much brighter than that of normal tissue upon TP laser irradiation (Figure S18). This was mainly due to the specific activation of MOF@Y-apt by the high expressed hypoxia-related reductase (low expression in normal tissues) in tumor tissues. Next, we explored the role of TP laser regulation in MOF@Y-apt-incubated tumor tissues. As shown in A­(b,c), compared with the non-irradiated group (exhibited obvious FRET signals of Cy5), the irradiated MOF@Y-apt-treated group showed bright Cy3 fluorescence. For the irradiated group, the fluorescence ratio of Cy3/Cy5 increased significantly compared with the non-irradiated group (B­(b,c)), indicating that the strategy can be used for spatiotemporal controlled imaging of mitochondria ATP in mice tumor tissues. Subsequently, the nanodevice was further applied to NaN3- and CaCl2-pretreated tumor tissue slices to determine the fluctuation of ATP. As shown in B­(d,e), the Cy3 fluorescence attained from CaCl2-pretreated tissues showed an increase obviously (R Cy3/Cy5 = 23.2) relative to the untreated group (R Cy3/Cy5 = 11.6), while NaN3-treated tissues showed the opposite trend (R Cy3/Cy5 = 1.54). Taken together, these data strongly support the potential of using MOF@Y-apt as a smart nanodevice to image ATP in mouse tumor tissues.

Lane 1: Ya; lane 2: Yb; lane 3: Yc-PC; lane 4: double strand formed by hybridization of Ya and Yb (Ya + Yb); lane 5: double strand formed by hybridization of Ya and Yc-PC (Ya + Yc-PC); lane 6: double strand formed by hybridization of Yb and Yc-PC (Yb + Yc-PC); and lane 7: Y-apt. The final concentration of the DNA samples was 1 μM. (C) SYBR Green-stained 12% PAGE imaging. The final concentration of the DNA samples was 1 μM. For the required light irradiation, 365 nm light at a density of 2.2 mW·cm–2 was applied for 10 min. The concentration of ATP was 10 mM.

cln_elements.content: (A) Confocal fluorescence images of MCF-7 cells upon different treatments. (a) MCF-7 cells incubated with culture medium (without addition of MOF@Y-apt) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h were taken as control; (b) MCF-7 cells incubated with MOF@Y-apt (0.1 mg·mL–1) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h; (c) MCF-7 cells incubated with MOF@Y-apt (0.1 mg·mL–1) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h, followed by light irradiation; (d) MCF-7 cells were pre-treated with 10 mM NaN3 for 1 h and then incubated with MOF@Y-apt (0.1 mg·mL–1) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h, followed by light irradiation; and (e) MCF-7 cells were pre-treated with 5 mM CaCl2 for 1 h and then incubated with MOF@Y-apt (0.1 mg·mL–1) under hypoxic conditions (5% O2) for 4 h, followed by light irradiation. For the required light irradiation, 365 nm light at a density of 2.2 mW·cm–2 was applied for 10 min. The excitation wavelength of the Cy3 channel (cyan, 570–620 nm) was 561 nm and that of the Cy5 channel (orange, 625–680 nm) was 561 nm and Cy5.5 channel (pink, 663–738 nm) was 640 nm. Scale bar: 20 μm. (B) Corresponding ratio (Cy3/Cy5.5) fluorescence intensity of (A). Error bars represent standard deviations from three repeated experiments.
